name: Poodle
description: Standard Poodles are intelligent, athletic dogs with moderate health risks. They're prone to bloat (a life-threatening emergency), Addison's disease, and joint issues. Their hybrid vigor makes them healthier than some breeds, but insurance is still recommended.

healthRisks.notes: Poodles have elevated risk for this hormonal disorder

faqs.question: What is bloat and why are Poodles at risk?
faqs.answer: Bloat (Gastric Dilatation-Volvulus) is when the stomach twists, cutting off blood flow. It's fatal without emergency surgery. Standard Poodles are at high risk due to their deep chests. Surgery costs $2,500-$7,500+.

faqs.question: What is Addison's disease?
faqs.answer: Addison's disease is an adrenal gland disorder where the body doesn't produce enough hormones. Poodles have a genetic predisposition. It requires lifelong medication ($50-200/month) but is manageable with proper treatment.

faqs.question: Is pet insurance worth it for a Poodle?
faqs.answer: Yes. While Poodles are healthier than many purebreds, bloat alone can cost $7,500+ for emergency surgery. Addison's disease adds ongoing medication costs. Insurance provides important financial protection.

faqs.question: Do Miniature and Toy Poodles have the same health issues?
faqs.answer: Smaller Poodles have lower bloat risk but higher risk for dental problems and luxating patella (knee issues). All sizes share risks for Addison's disease and eye problems.

faqs.question: When should I insure my Poodle?
faqs.answer: Insure as a puppy before any conditions develop. Addison's disease typically appears between ages 2-6, so having coverage in place early is important. Most insurers have waiting periods of 2-14 days.
